bibl.title: Chin Quock Wah vs. Henry M. White
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: Western District Court of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT, IN AN FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Application of CHIN QUOCK WAH, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus ) No. 2971 Stipulation

IT IS HEREBY AGREED AND STIPULATED by and between Adam Beeler, Attorney for Petitioner Chin Quock Wah, and Clay Allen and George B. Fishburn, United States District Attorney and Assistant United States District Attorney for the United States Government, that the Petitioner, by and through his attorney Adam Beeler, may file a Further Amended Petition in the above entitled case.
Dated this 9 day of March, 1915.
div1.ab: Clay Allen Attorneys for United States Government. Adam Beeler Attorney for Petitioner Chin Quock Wah.
div1.p: IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT, IN AND FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.

In the Matter of the Application of CHIN QUOCK WAH, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus. ) No. 2971 Further amended Petition of CHIN QUOCK WAH, by and through Adam Beeler, of the Law Firm of Beeler & Sullivan, his attorney.

Comes now Adam Beeler, of the Firm of Beeler & Sullivan, as Attorney for and in behalf, of Chin Quock Wah, an alleged alien, an alleged subject of the Emperor of China, and a son of Chin We Hue, a Merchant of the City of Boston, State of Massachusetts, and respectfully makes this application for a Writ of Habeas Corpus, and alleges as follows:

I. That the said Chin Quock Wah, is imprisoned and restrained of his liberty, by the U. S. Commissioner of Immigration, Henry M. White, or by some person or persons acting through, by or under him, and that said Chin Quock Wah, is imprisoned at the Detention House at the Immigration Station, in the City of Seattle, King County,,State of Washington, and within the jurisdiction of the above entitled Court, under the charge that the said Chin Quock Wah, is an alien, a subject to the Emperor of China, and has no lawful right to be admitted into the United States, and that he should be deported according to law, and your petitioner further informs the Honorable Court that said imprisonment, confinement and restraint and Order of Deportation is illegal, and arises from the following gacts, to-wit: That the said Chin Quock Wah, arrived at the Port of Seattle, on voyage from China, on the 14th day of September, 1914, and said Chin Quock Wah, was denied admittance into the United States on the ground that he was not legally entitled to be admitted therein; that said Chin Quock Wah -1-
was given a hearing by the by the Immigration Officials, on or about the 15th or 16th days of September, 19154; that further evidence was taken in said case by the Department of Labor, through the Immigration Officials, on the 25th day of November, and an order was issued by the Commissioner of Immigration, at Seattle, finding that said Chin Quock Wah, was not entitled to remain in the United States, and that he should be deported; that about November 25, 1914, an appeal was taken by said Chin Quock Wah, through his attorney, and that on February 20, 1915, the said Order of Deportation was affirmed, and said Chin Quock Wah, ordered deported.

II Your petitioner is informed and believes and so states the fact to be, that said Commissioner of Immigration, Henry M. White, of Seattle, Washington, in charge of the District of Washington, or his agent or agents, official or officials, acting by, under or through him, or for the United States Government, is about to deport and return the said Chin Quock Wah to China, in violation of the Treaty relations between the United States and China, and in violation of the laws and statutes of the United States relation to the Chinese Exclusion Act, and in violation of the laws relation to the acts and powers of the Secretary of Labor and the Assistant Secretary of Labor, in that said Chin Quock Wah is being deprived of his liberty without due progress of law and without being given a fair hearing by said Commissioner of Immigration, Henry M. White, or his agents or officials acting by and under or through him, or for the United States Government.

III Your Petitioner further alleges that the right of appeal from said Finding of Commissioner of Immigration, Henry M. White, or his agents or officials acting by, under or through him, or for the United States Government in and for the District of Washington, by the statutes in such cases made and provided for in -2-
relation to the Chinese Exclusion Laws, has been violated and that his full rights have not been accorded to your Petitioner Chin Quock Wah in this: That W. B. Wilson is the Secretary of Labor, and that Louis Post is his only Assistant Secretary of Labor; that both of said officials, as your petitioner alleges upon information and belief, and believes the fact to be, were at their respective offices in the Capitol at Washington, doing the duties imposed upon them on the day that the said appeal of Chin Quock Wah was considered, and that upon said day andat said time that the appeal of the said Chin Quock Wah, to the Secretary of Labor, from the decision denying the right to enter and remain in the United States of Chin Quock Wah, came up for hearing and consideration, that said Secretary of Labor and the Assistant Secretary of Labor, were then and there present in their respective offices, and that the said Secretary of Labor or Assistant Secretary of Labor, under the statutes, should have considered and determined the said appeal of Chin Quock Wah, from the said adverse decision of the said Commissioner of Immigration, but that said Secretary of Labor and Assistant Secretary of Labor failed, neglected or refused so to do, and hence the said Chin Quock Wah, has been denied his right of appeal, according to law.

IV. Your Petitioner further alleges that one J. B. Densmore is the Solicitor of the Department of Labor, and further alleges that said J. B. Densmore attempted to perform the duties of the Secretary of Labor or Assistant Secretary of Labor while they were present in their respective offices, and the order of the President of the United States, with due respect thereto, does not authorize said J. B. Densmore, or such Solicitor of the Department of Labor, to perform the duties of the Secretary of Labor or the Assistant Secretary of Labor, save and except in their absence, and therefore, the action of said J. B. Densmore in claiming to be the acting Secretary of Labor, during the presence of said officials then and there, is a usurption of the duties imposed upon the said Secretary of Labor, by Congress, and the -3-
said J. B. Densmore, in assuming the duties of the said Secretary of Labor, and the Assistant Secretary of Labor, and affirming the Finding of the Commissioner of Immigration at Seattle, Washington, in relation to the case of Chin Quock Wah, exceeded the statute, and his action in sustaining the adverse decision in relation to the right to enter and remain, of Chin Quock Wah, in the United States, is null and the said Chin Quock Wah, has been denied the right of appeal as provided by the statutes in such cases.

V Your Petitioner on information and belief, further states that the said Chin Quock Wah, has not had a fair and impartial trial before the said Commissioner of Immigration, at Seattle, King County, Washington, that there is no evidence in the records to sustain the Department's Exclusion and Deportation Order; that said Chin Quock Wah, after the Department had illegally ordered his exclusion from entry into the United States, and his deportation therefrom, without any authority of law, by the illegal act of said Solicitor J. B. Densmore, or by whomever said order was issued, was denied a fair and impartial trial, in accordance with law, in that the record does not show who signed the Order of Deportation, and it further appears upon said record, that it was signed by the Assistant Secretary, without naming who the Assistant Secretary of the Department of Labor is;And also that Chin Quock Wah, was denied further, in that at the time of his hearing before the Commissioner of Immigration, at Seattle, Washington, Henry M. White, or by some person or persons acting by, or under said Commissioner of Immigration, that said Chin Quock Wah, was not allowed to consult counsel, or was he advised of his right to have counsel, and that he was further denied the right to have witnesses, for and in his behalf, and he was nor appraised of his right to have witnesses appear for and in his behalf; that said Chin Quock Wah, was denied the right to face his witnesses, and that evidence was taken without said Chin Quock Wah, being -4-
then and there, facing said witnesses, and he was not appraised of his right to cross-examine said witnesses, who gave evidence against him for and in behalf of the Government.

VI Your Petitioner further alleges that Chin Quock Wah, is the minor son of an American Citizen, and that to deny him of his right to enter and remain in the United States, is depriving him of his liberty, without due process of law, and is in violation of the Constitution of the United States.

WHEREFORE, your Petitioner prays that this Court find that said Chin Quock Wah, has not been accorded the rights and privileges allowed by the treaty between the United States and China, and that he be discharged and allowed to join his father, who is a merchant in Boston, Massachusetts.
Dated this 8th day of March, 1915.
div1.ab: Adam Beeler Attorney for Chin Quock Wah.
div1.p: STATE OF WASHINGTON, COUNTY OF KING. ) SS

ADAM BEELER, being first duly sworn, on oath deposes and says: That he is one of the attorneys for the said Chin Quock Wah; that he has read the foregoing Further Amended Petition, knows the contents thereof, and that the same is true of his own knowledge; that those facts which he does not know of his own knowledge, he alleges upon information and belief to be true.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 9th day of March, 1915.
div1.ab: James H Doyle Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle.
div1.p: Original. No. 2971.
In the United States District Court, in and for the Western District of Washington, Northern Division.
In the Matter of the Application of CHIN QUOCK WAH, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
FURTHER AMENDED PETITION and STIPULATION.
BEELER & SULLIVAN Attorneys for Petitioner. 510-11 White Bldg. Seattle, Wash.
2x
FILED IN THE U. S. District Court, Western Dist. of Washington, NORTHERN DIVISION MAR131915
div1.ab: FRANK L. CROSBY, Clerk, By EML Deputy
